Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Vitamin Supplementation on Cardiovascular Health

Background: Vitamins are essential for maintaining cardiovascular function, and deficiencies may contribute to cardiovascular abnormalities. This study examines the role of vitamin supplementation in preventing cardiovascular disease (CVD).

Methods: A randomised controlled trial was conducted at a cardiovascular clinic. Participants were adults with cardiovascular risk factors. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Blinding was maintained for participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors. Sample size calculation was based on detecting a significant difference in cardiovascular events.

Participants: A total of 200 participants were recruited and randomised, with 100 assigned to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Intervention: The intervention group received a combination of hydrophilic and lipophilic vitamins, while the control group received a placebo.

Objective: To assess the efficacy of vitamin supplementation in reducing the incidence of CVD.

Outcome: The primary outcome was the incidence of cardiovascular events over a 12-month period.

Results: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach. The intervention group experienced a significant reduction in cardiovascular events (mean difference = 5.2 events, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01). Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.

Interpretation: Vitamin supplementation may reduce the risk of CVD in individuals with cardiovascular risk factors. These findings suggest potential benefits of vitamins in CVD prevention, warranting further investigation.
